title: 104_hr125
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress emphasizes the importance of protecting citizens from armed criminals to maintain public safety and prosperity. Banning specific firearms does not deter criminals from acquiring weapons. The most effective way to protect the public from gun violence is not specified. The most effective way to protect the public from gun-wielding violent criminals is to arrest, convict, and incarcerate such predators, ensuring they serve sufficient sentences to prevent quick return to the streets. SEC. 3. ARMED VIOLENT CRIMINAL APPREHENSION DIRECTIVE. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets, considering factors like severe punishment, effectiveness of laws, resources, nature of crime, and limited Federal involvement. The Attorney General must ensure limited Federal involvement in prosecuting crimes traditionally handled by State and local jurisdictions. Each US attorney must report monthly on defendants charged with violating specific sections of the US Code. The Attorney General must also submit a biannual compilation to Congress. The Attorney General must submit a compilation of information received by the Department of Justice and a report on waivers granted under subsection (b), where a United States attorney can request a waiver from the Attorney General for certain requirements. The Attorney General can grant waivers based on established guidelines. The Attorney General establishes guidelines for waivers requested by United States attorneys based on the number of assistant attorneys and level of violent crime in the district. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as someone accused of violating specific sections of the United States Code. The section shall expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act, violating section 924 of the title. Repeal of prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. Amendments are made to various sections of title 18, United States Code, including the removal of subsections (v) and (w) in Section 922, the striking of paragraph (30) in Section 921(a), modifications to Section 921(a)(31)(A), the removal of the last 2 sentences in Section 923(i), and changes to Section 924(a)(1)(B) by removing references to subsections (r), (v), and (w). Section 110104 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 (18 U.S.C. 921 note) is repealed, removing references to subsections (v) and (w) in Section 922. SEC. 5 mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include harsher penalties for individuals who possess a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code imposes increased sentences for individuals who use a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Depending on the severity of the offense, the sentences range from 5 to 20 years of imprisonment. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code imposes increased sentences for individuals who use a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession of a firearm during a second or subsequent conviction results in additional imprisonment of 10 years or 30 years depending on the type of firearm. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates increased sentences for individuals using a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession of a firearm during a second or subsequent offense results in additional imprisonment of 20 to 25 years, depending on the circumstances. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates increased sentences for individuals using a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession of a firearm during a second or subsequent offense results in additional imprisonment of not less than 30 years, or life imprisonment if the firearm is a machinegun, destructive device, or equipped with a silencer or muffler. Probationary sentences are not allowed for those convicted under this subsection. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates increased sentences for individuals using a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Violators sentenced under this subsection cannot have their term run concurrently with any other imprisonment, and they cannot be released for any reason during their sentence. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on March 22, 1996.
